abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>Tanytarsus</jats:italic>van der Wulp, with 355 currently known valid species, is a comparatively large genus of nonbiting midges (Diptera: Chironomidae). Relationships among<jats:italic>Tanytarsus</jats:italic>and associated genera and among species in the genus have been exceptionally difficult to resolve using morphology or single gene genealogies. Here, the phylogeny of<jats:italic>Tanytarsus</jats:italic>sensu lato is reconstructed based on the combined analysis of five nuclear markers, including both ribosomal (18S) and protein‐coding (AATS1, CAD, PGD and TPI) genes. Our results indicate that<jats:italic>Tanytarsus</jats:italic>is paraphyletic with<jats:italic>Caladomyia</jats:italic>Säwedal placed among South American<jats:italic>Tanytarsus</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>Virgatanytarsus</jats:italic>Pinder as part of a Gondwanan clade, and<jats:italic>Corynocera</jats:italic>Zetterstedt within the<jats:italic>Tanytarsus norvegicus</jats:italic>(Kieffer) species group. Based on these results, we synonymize<jats:italic>Caladomyia</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>Virgatanytarsus</jats:italic>with<jats:italic>Tanytarsus</jats:italic>. We propose retaining the older name<jats:italic>Corynocera</jats:italic>until an eventual International Code of Zoological Nomenclature ruling on precedence can be made regarding the more frequent usage of the younger name<jats:italic>Tanytarsus</jats:italic>. As expected, the previously synonymized<jats:italic>Nimbocera</jats:italic>Reiss is confirmed to be a junior synonym of<jats:italic>Tanytarsus</jats:italic>with<jats:italic>T</jats:italic>.<jats:italic>rhabdomantis</jats:italic>(Trivinho‐Strixino & Strixino) grouping with other Neotropical<jats:italic>Tanytarsus</jats:italic>. The genus<jats:italic>Sublettea</jats:italic>Roback remains valid outside of<jats:italic>Tanytarsus</jats:italic> + <jats:italic>Cladotanytarsus</jats:italic>Kieffer. The monophyly of some established species groups is well supported, while other groups are refuted or remain uncertain. Based on a calibrated molecular divergence time analysis,<jats:italic>Tanytarsus</jats:italic>diverged from its sister group<jats:italic>Cladotanytarsus</jats:italic>during the Late Cretaceous to Early Paleogene (61–79 Ma). The genus most likely originated in the Oriental and Palearctic regions.</jats:p>
title: Molecular phylogeny and temporal diversification ofTanytarsusvan der Wulp (Diptera: Chironomidae) support generic synonymies, a new classification and centre of origin
